name: Tikil Gomen
recipe: Sauté onion, turmeric, and vegetables in oil until soft.
tip: Very easy on the stomach, high in fiber.
culture: Common during fasting seasons in Ethiopian households.

name: Azifa
recipe: Cook lentils, cool them, then mix with other ingredients.
tip: Served cold — great protein source for vegans.
culture: Often served as a light side dish or fasting meal.

name: Enkulal Firfir
recipe: Scramble eggs with sautéed onion and tomato.
culture: Common breakfast across all Ethiopian regions.

name: Tihlo
recipe: Roll cooked barley dough into balls, dip in meat sauce.

name: Fossolia
recipe: Sauté vegetables in oil with garlic and spices.
tip: Good side dish — high in vitamin A and C.
culture: Often cooked during Christian fasting periods.

name: Siljo
recipe: Mix fava bean flour with spices and cook until thick. Often served cold with injera during fasting.
tip: Filling and high in plant protein — ideal for lent and vegan diets.
culture: Common Orthodox Christian fasting food served on holidays like Fasika and Meskel.

name: Kitfo
recipe: Mix freshly minced beef with spiced clarified butter and mitmita. Can be served raw (lebleb) or lightly cooked.
tip: Excellent source of protein and iron for strength and energy.
culture: A signature Gurage dish often served with kocho and ayib during holidays and special events.

name: Bula
recipe: Stir enset starch with hot water over low heat until it thickens into porridge. Serve warm with niter kibbeh and berbere.
tip: Energizing and good for digestion — often eaten for stamina.
culture: Traditional food of southern Ethiopia, including Sidama and Wolaita communities.

name: Dulet
recipe: Finely chop and fry beef organs with onion, garlic, chili, and spices until flavorful.
tip: Packed with vitamins and nutrients from organ meats.
culture: Often eaten with injera; popular among meat lovers and served at gatherings.

name: Suf
recipe: Eaten roasted or raw; also ground for oil or flour.
tip: High in healthy fats and vitamin E — great for skin and heart.
culture: Popular as a snack during holidays and coffee ceremonies.

name: Difo Dabo
recipe: Mix and knead dough with yeast and spices. Wrap in leaves and bake until golden.
tip: Slow-digesting energy-rich bread — perfect for special occasions.
culture: Prepared for Meskel, weddings, and Sunday church meals.

name: Beso Chibto
recipe: Mix roasted barley flour with melted niter kibbeh and sweetener. Serve warm or room temp.
tip: Great for quick energy during travel or fasting.
culture: Popular among Oromo and Amhara communities — often eaten by students or travelers.
